name: Creeping Ludwigia
description: Ludwigia repens, commonly known as Creeping Ludwigia or Red Ludwigia, is a fast-growing aquatic and semi-aquatic plant native to parts of North and Central America, including the southern United States, Mexico, and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Onagraceae (evening primrose) family and features oval to lanceolate leaves (2-4 cm long, 1-2 cm wide) arranged in opposite pairs along branching stems. The leaves are typically green when grown under low light, but develop intense red, orange, or bronze coloration under high light conditions. The stems are reddish-brown to red. This plant displays an upright to semi-upright growth habit and can reach 20-50 cm in height. Leaves develop intense red coloration under high light conditions. It produces small, yellow, four-petaled flowers when grown emersed. In its native habitat, it grows in shallow water, marshes, and along the edges of ponds and streams. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds vibrant red-orange accents to aquatic setups. It's popular in aquascaping for its colorful foliage and ability to provide striking contrast.
